pullRequest.body:
Some initial definitions introducing a model of oracle computability via partial recursive functions, defining Turing reducibility and equivalence, and proving that Turing equivalence is an equivalence relation. We define the type of Turing degrees as equivalence classes under Turing equivalence and prove that it forms a partial order under reducibility. This PR includes:

- `RecursiveIn f g`: An inductive definition representing that a partial function `f` is recursive in oracle `g`, ie. `f` reduces to `g`.
- `TuringEquivalent`: A relation defining Turing equivalence between partial functions.
- `TuringDegree`: The type of Turing degrees, defined as equivalence classes under `TuringEquivalent`.
- A proof that TuringDegree is a partial order when reducibility is lifted to degrees

### Implementation Notes

The type `RecursiveIn f g` is inductively defined to include basic functions such as `zero`, `succ`, projections, and the oracle `g`, and is closed under pairing, composition, primitive recursion, and μ-recursion. The `join` operation combines two partial functions by mapping even and odd numbers to the respective functions.

### Notation
- `f ≡ᵀ g`: `f` is Turing equivalent to `g`.

## In Progress
The work here is just the basic definitions for the theory being developed. Some current in-progress work involves proving the upper-semilattice structure of Turing degrees, proving the existence of a _relativized_ universal partial recursive function, proving properties of the jump operator, and proving that degrees are not totally ordered (Kleene-Post theorem).

### References

* [Carneiro2018] Carneiro, Mario. *Formalizing Computability Theory via Partial Recursive Functions*. arXiv preprint arXiv:1810.08380, 2018.
* [Odifreddi1989] Odifreddi, Piergiorgio. *Classical Recursion Theory: The Theory of Functions and Sets of Natural Numbers, Vol. I*. Springer-Verlag, 1989.
* [Soare1987] Soare, Robert I. *Recursively Enumerable Sets and Degrees*. Springer-Verlag, 1987.
* [Gu2015] Gu, Yi-Zhi. *Turing Degrees*. Institute for Advanced Study, 2015.

### Tags

Computability, Oracle, Turing Degrees, Reducibility, Equivalence Relation

### PR summary [a7d656b8bd](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20301/commits/a7d656b8bd1e20f504d0d72a48bfe8ef5b46ed15)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Computability.TuringDegrees` (new file)|572|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Nat.Partrec.recursiveIn`
`+ RecursiveIn`
`+ RecursiveIn.partrec_of_zero`
`+ RecursiveIn.refl`
`+ RecursiveIn.trans`
`+ TuringDegree`
`+ TuringDegree.isPartialOrder`
`+ TuringEquivalent`
`+ TuringEquivalent.equivalence`
`+ TuringEquivalent.refl`
`+ TuringEquivalent.symm`
`+ TuringEquivalent.trans`
`+ instance : IsPreorder (ℕ →. ℕ) RecursiveIn`
`+ instance : IsRefl (ℕ →. ℕ) RecursiveIn`
`+ instance : IsTrans (ℕ →. ℕ) RecursiveIn`
`+ partrec_iff_partrec_in_everything`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Thanks for reopening this PR from a branch!
Do you mean `recursive in` instead of `reducible to`?

a styile nit (to apply throughout):
```suggestion
  induction fRecInZero with
  | zero =>
```
etc (this is only valid if you change all the `case` lines)

```suggestion
@[refl]
theorem RecursiveIn.refl (f : ℕ →. ℕ) : RecursiveIn f f :=
```

Style nit: statements should be indented one level further than the proof:
```suggestion
theorem RecursiveIn.trans {f g h : ℕ →. ℕ} (hg : RecursiveIn f g) (hh : RecursiveIn g h) :
    RecursiveIn f h := by
  induction hg
```
(and throughout)

```suggestion
theorem TuringEquivalent.trans {f g h : ℕ →. ℕ} (h1 : f ≡ᵀ g) (h2 : g ≡ᵀ h) : f ≡ᵀ h :=
```
will make dot notation more effective here.

to make it clearer what you're defining here:
```suggestion
abbrev TuringDegree : Type _ :=
```

This doesn't really match the Lean definition; I think more appropriate would be
```suggestion
/-- The type of Turing degrees, implemented as the quotient of partial functions (`PFun`) under Turing equivalence. -/
```

Generally we prefer to omit docstrings that are a literal "symbol reading" of the lean code. This is analogous to writing `i++; // add one to i` in C++.

(this comment applies to many docstrings in this PR, not just this one)
Please add these to `references.bib`, if they are not already there.

super nit: blank line between the imports and the start of this comment:
```suggestion

/-!
```

Could you add a docstring to `rfind` and `prec`, that explain what these shorthands refer to? The syntax is
```lean
  /-- docstring -/
  | rfind (f g : ℕ →. ℕ) (hf : RecursiveIn f g) :
```
Is this one "μ-recursion."?

I wonder if it makes sense to have multiple oracles here? That is, to change this to
```
inductive RecursiveIn (ι : Sort*) : (ℕ →. ℕ) → (oracles : ι → ℕ →. ℕ) → Prop
  | oracle (i) : RecursiveIn (oracles i) oracles
  -- etc
```
What's nice about this definition is that we can redefine `PartRec = RecursiveIn Empty`.

@digama0 might have more thoughts on whether this is actually a good idea.
